text:
Mandip Rai, director at the LLEP (Image: Beth Walsh) 
Mandip Rai was appointed director of the Leicester and Leicestershire Enterprise Partnership last autumn. 
He had previously spent two years as the LLEP’s head of strategy and engagement. 
He was an inward investment executive at the Department of Trade and Industry before taking up the post of economic development and regeneration manager at Hinckley and Bosworth Borough Council. 
From there he moved to Leicestershire County Council as head of economic policy and partnerships before moving to the LLEP in 2011 
He holds a BA in town planning from the University of Westminster and a masters in local economic development from Middlesex University. 13:24 Nick Pulley 
Nick Pulley, chair, LLEP and Mids Engine 
Nick Pulley, who is the chair of the Leicester and Leicestershire Enterprise Partnership was appointed to chair the £250 million Midlands Engine Investment Fund last year. 
He is also regional director for Santander Corporate and Commercial, which is the bank’s corporate lending arm, where he has held senior positions since 1999. 
The aim of the Midlands Engine is to create 300,000 jobs and generate an additional £34 billion for the Midlands economy by 2030. 
The investment fund is an amalgamation of revenues from 11 LEP’s from across the region, together with a £90 million loan from the European Investment Bank. 
Nick Pulley believes that the East Midlands and West Midlands working in partnership can achieve a major positive change for business in the region, with all 86 local authorities working together. 
He took over as chair of the LLEP in 2014, having previously been a board member and chair of the Regional Growth Fund grant panel. 13:23 Diane Postle 
Diane Postle, chair, Rainbows 
Diane Postle is chairwoman of Rainbows – the Loughborough based hospice which supports terminally ill children and their families from across the East Midlands. 
She was previously the hospice’s clinical trustee for nursing. 
She is a qualified general nurse, midwife and health visitor and sits on the clinical quality assurance committee. 
Before joining Rainbows she held various senior nursing posts in the NHS, working with acute care, community and general practice. She is deputy director of nursing and quality at Kettering General Hospital. 13:22 Marion Plant OBE 
Marion Plant OBE, North Warks and Hinckley College and South Leics College 
Marion Plant OBE is the principal and chief executive of North Warwickshire and Hinckley College and South Leicestershire College. She is also chief executive of the Midland Academies Trust which sponsors six secondary schools. 
In 2015 she was appointed a non-executive board member of the DfE. 
She is a board member of the Leicester and Leicestershire Local Enterprise Partnership and a member of the board of the Coventry and Warwickshire LEP. 
She is a member of the Church of England Board of Education, vice-chair of the England Colleges Football Association and the West Midlands champion for World Skills and a member of the Skills Show board. 
She received the OBE in 2009 for services to further education. 
She grew up in Zambia and worked in the NHS before moving into education. 13:21 Sir John Peace 
Sir John Peace, chair, Midlands Engine 
Sir John Peace is the man tasked with ensuring that the Midlands is able to power ahead with a vision to be the beating economic heart of the country. 
He leads the Midlands Engine, a partnership of business, academia and local authorities aimed at driving up growth in the region. As such he is one of the most influential people in the Midlands business community. 
Sir John, who is Lord Lieutenant of the County of Nottinghamshire, comes from Caunton near Newark, the son of a coal miner. 
He is chairman of the multinational bank Standard Chartered and non-executive chairman of Burberry Group. 
He is also chairman of Midlands Connect, developing a transport strategy to improve the connectivity of the region’s key locations. 
He went to the Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst from school and after that joined Great Universal Stores plc, rising to group chief executive. 
Sir John Peace was also chairman of financial analysts, Nottingham-based Experian, the group he spun out of GUS in 2006 and which now employs 2000 people. He stepped down from Experian in 2014. 
He joined the board of Standard Chartered in 2007 as deputy chairman and was appointed chairman in 2009. 13:20 
Blake Pain, leader of District Council Blake Pain 
Blake Pain this week resigned as the leader of Harborough District Council. His successor has yet to be selected. 
He is Conservative councillor for the Lubenham ward which he has represented since 2007. 
He is a member of the Leicestershire County Council cabinet, representing the Bruntingthorpe division, the Leicester and Leicestershire Enterprise Partnership, the county council’s highway forum and the East Midlands Council. 
He supports the Foxton Locks Partnership and the Robert Monk Foxton charity. 
He also supports the Spark business support initiative to encourage business growth and entrepreneurship. 13:20 Joe Orson 
Joe Orson, leader, Melton Borough Council 
Joe Orson represents the Old Dalby ward on Melton Borough Council, which is made up of seven villages. He was appointed leader in May. 
As well as being leader of the council he chairs the policy, finance and administration committee and sits on the Melton Community Partnership, the Welland Partnership Board, the budget and strategic planning working group and the cattle market working group. 
He is the East Midlands councils representative on the Local Government Association general assembly. 
One of his priorities as leader is to progress the Melton local plan and continue to press for a by-pass. 13:19 
Neil O’Brien, MP for Harborough, Oadby and Wigston Harborough MP Neil O'Brien 
Before the election he worked at 10 Downing Street where he was an advisor to the Prime Minister on the economy, specifically working on the Midlands Engine plan. 
He previously worked at the Treasury, concentrating on a number of areas including education improvement, crime reduction and the reform of the planning system. 
Married to a doctor, he has supported several health-related issues including investment in local hospitals, support for victims of heart disease and stroke, and support for dementia sufferers. 
He is also part of the campaign to save Glenfield Children’s Heart Unit. 13:17 
David Monteith, Dean of Leicester 
Ulsterman David Monteith was installed as the Dean of Leicester Cathedral in 2013. 
One of his biggest jobs was to handle the events and international attention on the cathedral for the re-internment of Richard III. 
He had been part of the Cathedral since 2009 as Canon Chancellor responsible for the pastoral and educational life of the Cathedral. 
Born in Enniskillen, he holds a degree in zoology from Durham University, and studied theology at St John’s Nottingham, where he achieved an MA in mission and ministry. 
He was ordained as a priest in 1994, serving initially in Birmingham before joining the ministry of St Martin-in-the-Fields in Westminster. 13:16 
Nicky Morgan, MP for Loughborough Nicky Morgan has reported threats on Twitter to the police 
Nicky Morgan was elected as Conservative MP for Loughborough in 2010. Four years later she was made Secretary of State for Education and Minister for Women and Equalities. 
She left the Cabinet in a Theresa May reshuffle. 
She had previously been Economic Secretary to the Treasury, an assistant Government whip and Parliamentary Private Secretary to the Rt Hon. David Willetts when he was minister for Universities and Science. 
She served on the Business, Innovation and Skills Select Committee. 
Before entering parliament she was a corporate law solicitor, having studied law at Oxford. 
Her husband Jonathan, an architect, has served as a councillor for Loughborough Outwoods ward for the past 17 years. 13:16 Tim Maxted 
Tim Maxted, chairman, Berkeley Insurance Group 
Tim Maxted led the management buyout of Berkeley in 2008 and has built the business up, while establishing a reputation for client service and a depth of knowledge. 
Berkeley continues to expand and will soon be taking more space in its smart Colton Square headquarters. 
Tim Maxted was appointed as High Sheriff of Leicestershire in April. 
His aim during his time in office is to bring together business and charities. 
Berkeley provides cover for some of the UK’s iconic and complex buildings and projects, including the Manhattan Loft Gardens project in East London which involves a 36-floor development of apartments with three ‘sky gardens’ for residents, plus a hotel. 
Berkeley is proud of its stable client base – in Leicestershire where Tim Maxted is happy to be seen as the “local broker” and in the wider UK. 13:14 
Steve Lunn, Leic. Chief Fire and Rescue Officer Chief fire officer Steve Lunn 
Steve Lunn was appointed was appointed to head up the service last year, having previously held the role of director of community safety which incorporates fire prevention, emergency response and fire protection. 
He has just announced his intention to retire from the £126,000 a year post at the end of the year. 
Based at the service’s Birstall HQ, he has spent more than 30 years in the Fire and Rescue Service in a wide variety of roles from operational firefighter to head of the service in the county. 
Leicestershire Fire and Rescue Service has more than 800 employees and 80 appliances and vehicles spread over 20 stations. 
The Leicestershire Fire and Rescue Service was created in 1974 when the City of Leicester brigade was merged with the Leicestershire and Rutland brigade 13:13 Lord Lieutenant of Leicestershire, Jennifer, Lady Gretton, 
Lord Lieutenant of Leicestershire, Jennifer, Lady Gretton, Commemoration of Passchendaele at Leicester Cathedral.. Colonel Murray Colville greets Lady Gretton. 
On 24 February 2003 Lady Gretton was appointed a Justice of the Peace and Keeper of the Rolls for Leicestershire. 
She is a past chairman of the Lord Chancellor’s Advisory Committee on Justices of the Peace a committee on which she is still a member. 
In 2004, she was made a Dame of the Order of St John and holds honorary degrees with Leicestershire’s three universities. 
In the 2017 Birthday Honours List she was made a Dame Commander of the Royal Victorian Order. 
Lady Gretton (Jennifer Ann) was born on 14th June 1943 at St Ives, Cornwall. She is the widow of the Third Baron Gretton, and has a married son (the Fourth Baron Gretton), and a married daughter. Lady Gretton has three granddaughters and three grandsons. 
Lady Gretton took over the Stapleford Estate following the death of her husband in 1989. Today the estate is run by her son, The Lord Gretton, with Lady Gretton maintaining a keen interest. 13:12 David Tredinnick, MP for Bosworth 
David Tredinnick, MP for Bosworth 
David Tredinnick has been the MP for Bosworth since 1987. 
He was born in 1950 and educated at Eton College, Mons Officer Cadet School, St John’s College, Oxford (M.Litt), and the Graduate School of Business at Cape Town University (MBA). 
His main area of interest is health and he has been chairman of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Integrated Healthcare since 2002. 
The PGIH works to bring together the best of orthodox and complementary healthcare for the benefit of patients. 13:09 Pauline Tagg 
Pauline Tagg MBE, chairman, EMAS 
Pauline Tagg has worked in the NHS for more than 35 years as a nurse, midwife and senior manager. 
She has held executive nurse director posts in three NHS hospital trusts, the most recent being Leicester. 
She joined the East Midlands Ambulance Service board as a non-executive director in 2011 and became its chairman two years later. 
She was awarded the MBE in 2009 for her services to healthcare. She is a volunteer with Cancer Research UK in Melton Mowbray where she lives. 
Last year she had to deal with rumours that EMAS could be merged with West Midlands Ambulance Service but Pauline Tagg ruled it out, though the two services had discussed co-operation. 
EMAS provides emergency response to nearly five million people across Leicestershire, Rutland, Derbyshire, Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire and Northamptonshire. 13:09 
Sir Peter Soulsby, Leicester City Mayor Sir Peter Soulsby 
Sir Peter Soulsby became Leicester’s first elected mayor in 2011. He was re-elected in 2015. 
He was the Labour MP for Leicester South for six years from 2005. He resigned his seat to contest the mayoral election. 
Born in Bishop Auckland, he was a teacher before being elected to Leicester City Council in 1974. 
He served on the council for 30 years, 17 of them as council leader. 
He has been a passionate champion for the regeneration of Leicester and spearheaded the City Challenge programme, bringing jobs and investment to the city. 
He continues his efforts to bring development to the city centre, including the redevelopment of the former council offices in New Walk. 
A narrowboat enthusiast, he sits on the board of the Canals and Rivers Trust. He was knighted in 1999 for his services to local government. 13:08 Manjual Sood MBE 
Manjula Sood MBE, chair, Leicester Council of Faiths 
Councillor Manjula Sood – a Labour city councillor since 1996 arrived in the UK in 1970 and has lived in Leicester ever since. As an Asian woman her career has been a series of benchmarks and achievements. 
She qualified as a teacher from the University of Leicester and spent 20 years as a primary school teacher. In 1973 she was one of the first Asian female teachers in the city. Her late husband, Councillor Paul Sood was one of the first ethnic county councillors in the country. 
She was the UK’s first Asian female Lord Mayor in 2008 and the first sitting Lord Mayor of the city to receive an MBE which she was awarded for her community work. 
She has served three stints as High Bailiff up to this year – the first Asian female to hold the post. She is chair of the Leicester Council of Faiths which promotes a better understanding among faith communities. 
She is an active member of the Leicester Domestic Violence Forum and a member of the Asian Refuge Shelter. 13:04 The Rt Rev Martin Snow 
The Rt Rev Martin Snow, Bishop of Leicester 
Indonesian-born Martin Snow was appointed as Bishop of Leicester in 2015. 
At the time he was the youngest serving bishop in the Church of England at age 47. 
He had previously been the Suffragen Bishop of Tewkesbury since 2013. 
He was born in Indonesia where his parents worked as missionaries. 
He studied at Sheffield University and Wycliffe Hall, Oxford, serving his first curacy near Sheffield. 
Rev Martin Snow worked for the Church Mission Society in Guinea, West Africa from 1998 to 2001. 
From 2010 to 2013 he was Archdeacon of Sheffield and Rotherham. 
He is married to Dr Lynn Snow, a paediatrician. His interests include kayaking. 13:04 David Slater 
David Slater, leader, Charnwood Borough Council 
David Slater has been the Conservative leader of Charnwood Borough Council since 2011, representing the ward of Quorn and Mountsorrel Castle. 
He also serves on the council’s cabinet and personnel committee and is the county councillor for the Syston Ridgeway division. 
He worked at industrial electronics firm Takbro for 15 years where he was a divisional manager. 
He is a member of the Local Government Association, the District Councils Network and the East Midlands Councils Leaders Board. 
He is also a trustee of the Thomas Rawlins Education Charity and the Quorn Townlands Charity as well as being a member of the Leicester and Leicestershire Enterprise Partnership. 13:00 Sir Alec Jeffreys 
Sir Alec Jeffreys, DNA fingerprinting 
Sir Alec Jeffreys was a researcher at the University of Leicester when, in 1984, he identified individual patterns in human genomes. 
This became the basis for DNA fingerprinting and profiling, and transformed forensic medicine. 
His discovery arose when he was looking at an X-ray film image of a DNA experiment. 
He spotted differences and similarities between different members of his technician’s family. 
This paved the way for the development of DNA fingerprinting which uses genetic codes to identify individuals. 
He was made an honorary freeman of the City of Leicester in 1992 and knighted for services to genetics two years later. 
Other accolades he has received include the Albert Einstein World Award of Science and the Great Briton award. 13:00 
Sarah Harrison, Leicester city centre director 
Sarah Harrison took up her role as city centre director for Leicester eight years ago. 
She has the not inconsiderable brief of developing Leicester as the leading destination for retail, leisure, entertainment and heritage in the East Midlands. 
Richard III lent a hand, providing a huge opportunity to showcase the city to the world. 
That opportunity isn’t being wasted, with major retail and residential investment in the city centre and the development of a lively cultural quarter. 
Sarah Harrison came to Leicester with a great deal of international experience under her belt. 
She worked in Dubai promoting major developments in Dubai and Cairo, and before that was managing director of a boutique marketing consultancy in Covent Garden with clients in the UK and Spain. 
She has two degrees – a BA and an MBA in marketing – from the University of Toledo. 12:58 Ian Harrison 
Ian Harrison, regional director, Department for International Trade 
Ian Harrison is the Government’s man charged with encouraging businesses in the East Midlands to export their goods and services. 
He was appointed to the post of Department of International Trade regional director for the East Midlands early in 2014. 
Post Brexit, his role takes on added urgency, with a Government national target of getting 100,000 more companies exporting by 2020. 
He is optimistic, though, and says there are huge numbers of innovative and successful firms based in the East Midlands with the potential to become successful exporters. 
He worked at the East Midlands Development Agency from 2000 to 2011 as a business growth manager for enterprise. 
He is a founding partner of MSDUK, a not-for-profit organisation aimed at promoting diversity and inclusion across all sectors. 12:58 Coun Mike Hall 
Coun Mike Hall, leader, Hinckley & Bosworth Council 
Mike Hall became leader of Hinckley & Bosworth Borough Council in May 2015. Representing the Burbage, Sketchley and Stretton ward, he was first Conservative leader of the council since 2007. 
He was born in Leicester in 1958. 
He served as a borough councillor from 2003 to 2007 before being re-elected in 2015 when Conservatives swept to power in the local elections. 
He is an engineering graduate and previously worked as an IT and business adviser with major companies and organisations including the NHS, the BBC and Royal Mail. More On
